Award.AwardTitle: PLANTS (Preparing Leaders and Nurturing Tomorrow's Scientists): Increasing the diversity of plant scientists
Award.AbstractNarration: The PLANTS (Preparing Leaders and Nurturing Tomorrow's Scientists) program will support attendance of undergraduate students at the annual meeting of the Botanical Society of America (BSA). The goal is to increase the number of undergraduates from underrepresented groups who attend these meetings, and to increase their level of academic excellence and motivation to pursue advanced degrees in the plant sciences. It will build upon the success of past and current activities of the BSA in outreach and in promoting the involvement of students from underrepresented groups. The activity will include a supporting mentoring network of graduate students, post-docs, and faculty who will assist the students before, during and after the meetings. The mentors will work not only to interpret the content of scientific talks to the students, but also to point out the broader relevance and application of the discipline to the students, and pass on to the students the genuine intellectual excitement and involvement of the conference participants. Students will attend sessions designed for advanced undergraduates that discuss preparation for advanced work, such as preparation for graduate school and factors influencing success in graduate school and science careers. The students will have opportunities to explore their academic and research interests in the plant sciences and to broaden their career opportunities. Involvement of the BSA and engagement of members in these activities will address the critical need for continued diversity recruitment for the vitality of the discipline and will emphasize the importance of year-long individual involvement. These activities also will promote development of a set of best practices to support outreach and minority mentoring in research activities in the plant sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science will not thrive in the future unless it is equally accessible to students from all backgrounds, including those from groups that are currently under-represented. Access involves not only knowledge about the discipline, but also understanding the culture of science and feeling welcome as a participant in scientific endeavors and as a member of the scientific community. It is also critical to understand job opportunities in the area and how to prepare for them. The goal of the PLANTS program was to encourage students from under-represented backgrounds to become part of the scientific community and in particular, to help them understand the opportunities possible with an advanced degree and/or to learn about careers in the plant sciences.  Students interested in attending the annual national meeting of the Botanical Society of America (BSA) and several other botanical societies were selected from a national pool with the goal that the group would increase the diversity of undergraduates attending the annual scientific conference.

  The volunteer mentors who worked individually with each student were critical to the success of the students in this program. Each PLANTS student was assigned two volunteer mentors, one peer mentor (an advanced undergraduate or graduate student) and one senior mentor (a postdoctoral fellow, faculty member, or professional biologist). In addition to professional development workshops open to all conferences attendees, PLANTS students were required to attend at least three scientific presentations a day with a mentor and discuss the content of each of those talks with the mentor. Mentors contacted students before the meeting, attended social activities and scientific talks with the students, helped the students network with other students, faculty, and other professionals at the meeting, and in general, pointed out the broader relevance and application of the discipline to the students, passing on to the students the genuine intellectual excitement and involvement of the conference participants. The PLANTS organizers and many mentors maintained contact with students after the meetings and provided encouragement as they moved beyond college. 

   Each group of undergraduates was chosen so that as a group they contributed to the diversity of the BSA (2011-2015, 61 total PLANTS grant recipients; 39% Hispanic, 18% African-American/Black, 13% Native American, 3% multi-origin, 3% white veteran, 3% with disabilities, and 18% low income white or Asian-American; 69% were female).  Many of these students had non-traditional academic backgrounds for students pursuing graduate school. Omitting the 2015 group of students because most just graduated in 2016, a remarkable 71% of the PLANTS grant recipients from the first four years (48 students, 2011-2014) continued on to graduate work (masters or doctoral programs) in research areas covered by the PLANTS program and an additional 10% began careers in the plant sciences with their bachelors’ degrees. Among these 48 students, almost 40% earned prestigious fellowships from the National Science Foundation, Ford Foundation, or fellowships covering several years of graduate training. Often, many of these students took time to work between their undergraduate studies and joining doctoral programs, so our ability to keep in touch with these students for several years after their participation in the PLANTS program was critical to document their continued involvement in the plant sciences and the development of their careers.

  The PLANTS program directly impacted the students who participated in the program, as well as the graduate students, postdocs, faculty, and professionals who mentored these students. A total of 81 different mentors participated in the program over the five-year period. The success, enthusiasm, and contributions of the PLANTS participants have helped to make the plant sciences community more aware and proactive about supporting the diversity of plant scientists within the Society and the plant sciences as a whole. Women increased from 44% to 48% of the US members of BSA from 2011 to 2016.   An especially promising trend was that the US members of the BSA with backgrounds traditionally under-represented in the sciences also increased during this period, from less than 3.3% to 6.1% of membership.
